references: Reynolds, M. D. 1990. The ecology of spacing behavior in the Yellow-billed Magpie Pica nuttalli. Phd Thesis. Univ. of California, Berkeley.
Verbeek, N. A. M. 1973. The exploitation system of the Yellow-billed Magpie. Univ. Calif. Publ. Zool. 99:1-58.

Zeiner, D. C., W. F. Laudenslayer Jr., and K. E. Mayer (editors). 1990. California's Wildlife. Vol. 2. Birds. California Statewide Wildlife Habitat Relat. System, California. Resources Agency, Dept. Fish and Game, Sacramento, California.

Koenig, Walt and Mark D. Reynolds. 2009. Yellow-billed Magpie (Pica nuttalli), The Birds of North America Online (A. Poole, Ed.). Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Retrieved from the Birds of North America Online: http://bna.birds.cornell.edu/bna/species/180 doi:10.2173/bna.180.
Linsdale, J.M. 1937. The natural history of magpies. Pacific Coast Avifauna, No. 25. 234 pp.
Hayworth, A. M. and W. V. Weathers. 1984. Temperature regulation and climatic adaptation in Black-billed and Yellow-billed magpies. Condor 86:19-26.
Grinnell, J. and A. H. Miller. 1944. The distribution of the birds of California. Pac. Coast Avifauna no. 27. Cooper Ornithol. Club, Berkeley, CA.
habitat_description: The Yellow-billed magpie is endemic to California open oak woodlands and found primarily in the Central Valley, southern Coast Ranges, and Sierra Nevada foothills. This species is restricted to oak savannah habitat containing large trees scattered among broad expanses of open ground. Range completely within an area experiencing a Mediterranean type climate with hot, dry summers and cool, wet winters, to which it is physiologically adapted (Hayworth and Weathers 1984). Most common in valley floors, along gentle slopes, and in open areas with large trees either scattered and parklike or along stream courses (Grinnell and Miller 1944). Large insects and accessible water must be present all year (Grinnell and Miller 1944). Forages in grassland, pasture, cultivated fields, and orchards (Linsdale 1937, Grinnell and Miller 1944, Verbeek 1973, Reynolds 1990)(quoted directly from Koenig and Reynolds 2009). Inhabits valley foothill hardwood, valley foothill hardwood-conifer, valley foothill riparian, orchard vineyard, cropland, pasture, and urban habitats. Verbeek (1973) reported home range in Monterey Co. averaged about 40 ha (100 ac) during breeding season, and expanded to about 607 ha (1500 ac) in nonbreeding season (quoted directly from Green et al. based on Zeiner et al. 1990).
